mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Getting Unmodified HREF= Attribute Values in ver. 1.3
mail.body: Hello, Again, I have another problem with changed behavior in version 1.3 compared to 1.2. I am using LinkTag.getLink() to get the target of a link. In version 1.2 this returned the unadorned value of the HREF= attribute as it appeared in the HTML document. This is what I want and what I need. In version 1.3, the result is modified when the link is relative. I'm (currently) processing local files, not documents retrieved via network a URL and the relative links are being resolved to something like this: Input file name: "C:/SHS/Web/Biography/Biography.html" HTML fragment: "<a href="SHS.html"> ... </a>" getLlink() return value: " file://localhostC:/SHS/Web/Biography/SHS.html " Not only is this not what I want, it's also malformed, since the required slash between the (gratuitous) "localhost" and the (gratuitous) "C:/SHS/Web/Biography/" is missing. How can I get the original behavior? Thanks. Randy

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Getting Unmodified HREF= Attribute Values in ver. 1.3
mail.body: Hi, Following up on my latest lament... I'm using this method to get unmodified HREF= attribute values: private String linkHREF(LinkTag link) if (href != null) if (href != null) The documentation doesn't make clear if Tag.getAttribute() performs alphabetic case canonicalization on the attribute names in the tags in the HTML input and on its arguments, so I tried two of the 16 possible combinations of upper and lower case among four letters. Comments? Randall Schulz At 09:14 2003-05-27, Randall R Schulz wrote: file://localhostC:/SHS/Web/Biography/SHS.html "

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Getting Unmodified HREF= Attribute Values in ver. 1.3
mail.body: Randall, Attributes are stored in the hashtable with uppercase keys and getAttribute() converts it's argument to uppercase also. The two examples are the same. As Mark suggests, writing a visitor to handle links is probably the best approach. But you may want to override visitLinkTag() instead. File a bug report regarding " file://localhostC:/ ", we're pretty unix centric and just missed that one. Derrrick Randall R Schulz wrote: file://localhostC:/SHS/Web/Biography/SHS.html " http://www.objectstore.net/sourceforge https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: Hi Randall, I faced very similar problems when I migrated to 1.3. Basically I believe the structure now returned has more of a DOM face than a SAX one as earlier. Earlier all nodes were available at the base level. Today they are buried within other nodes. Hence your <A> is buried in the Code for extracing link tag is given in documentation of node. Reproducing it here for u: NodeList collectionList =3D new NodeList();=20 Node node;=20 =20 This will get link nodes at all levels. Dhaval http://www.objectstore.net/sourceforge _______________________________________________ Htmlparser-user mailing list Htmlparser-user@... https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: Dhaval, Thanks for the information. Does this mean that there is not a strictly stream-based way to examine a complete HTML document? I don't mean to be impertinent, but this seems like a weaker design than that used in version 1.2. I don't like having to build collections containing portions of the document's contents when all I'm doing is making a single pass over the file. I think a purely stream-oriented model, whenever suitable to the driving application, is distinctly preferred. Building DOM-like structures when there's no need for random access to their sub-structure seems like a waste of memory. If there's a way to preserve the kind of program design I was using, I'd really like to know about it. Thanks again. Randall Schulz At 00:12 2003-05-27, dhaval.udani@... wrote:

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: Hi Randall, Lets not get critical over the design of 1.3. I think it has helped to bring about a great degree of stability as well as correctness into the parser. The isitor pattern employed has helped a lotand its really visible to a person like me who has used the parser extensively in my project. I also had a stream-based approach and I managed to maintain the same through a recursive approach of searching the page and then reproducing it. If u let me know your design and your requirement, there will definitely be a way out, only that we will have to search for it. Dhaval http://www.objectstore.net/sourceforge _______________________________________________ Htmlparser-user mailing list Htmlparser-user@... https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: Marc, That's not really what I'm asking for. It's not stream oriented because it forces the entire file to be read and an array holding the entire set of links to be collected before I can process them. Nonetheless, Dhaval's solution worked fine. Now what I really need is unmodified HREF= attribute values. Randall Schulz At 09:58 2003-05-27, Marc Novakowski wrote: http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/VisitorPattern

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: The default Visitors may collect the tags into collections, but it = completely possible to write your own Visitor that handles each tag as = it is parsed in the source document. Just override the "visitTag()" = method and do what you want with each tag as it's parsed. Marc -----Original Message----- From: Randall R Schulz [mailto:rschulz@...] Sent: Tuesday, May 27, 2003 10:15 AM To: htmlparser-user@... Subject: RE: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3 Marc, That's not really what I'm asking for. It's not stream oriented because=20 it forces the entire file to be read and an array holding the entire=20 set of links to be collected before I can process them. mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Link Extraction from Tables w/ ver. 1.3
mail.body: Hi, I have a properly functioning link extraction program based on HTMLParser 1.2. I'm trying to convert it to HTMLParser 1.3 (the newly released final version). I've fixed up all the changed data types, but I'm finding that links (<A> tags) contained within tables are being skipped. If in my node processing loop I replace the calls to my internal node processing function (which is called only if the node is an instance of LinkTag) with System.out.println(node.toString()); (for all returned node types), I see tables coming through as "blobs," if you will. That is, I see the entire <TABLE> ... </TABLE> element in the output as a single node with none of its internal structure parsed. I've tried adding a TableScanner to the parser (using parser.addScanner(new TableScanner(parser, "-tb"));), a TableRowScanner (using parser.addScanner(new TableRowScanner("-tr", parser));) and a TableColumnScanner (using parser.addScanner(new TableColumnScanner("-tc"));), but to no avail. What am I missing? How to I process _all_ of the link tags within the input document? Thanks. Randall Schulz

Hello all, I am trying to automate the posting of a page. However to any information I request by typing a code it asks me to type what is writen in an image. This page also saves a cookie which is than used to read its session content to verify if what is on the image is the same of what is typed. If it is than it show the results. They do this to avoid web robots. Does any one know how to bypass this? Thanks in advance, C.F.

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Anyone working on a scripting interface..?
mail.body: I've just started working with HTMLParser and before I dive of the deep end and start coding something up was wondering if anyone was working on an (XML, perhaps) scripting language to driver the parser..? I.e., for a known web page, use a script to get relevant info from the page, populate form fields, submit and then parse more results... regards, David ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------------------ David HM Spector spector (at) zeitgeist.com software architecture network design security consultation technical due diligence technology planning needs analysis Office:(631)261-5013 http://www.zeitgeist.com Cell: (631)827-3132

Version 1.3 of the most popular HTML parser on sourceforge is now available. Four weeks of candidate testing have culminated in a very stable, production level product, with many new user requested features. Features added since 1.2 include: constructor(URLConnection) for POST and exotic GET improved character set handling hierarchically nested tags, i.e. tables scanners for each type of tag java beans for easy integration of text and link fetching 'visitor' patterns Wiki page documentation improved script scanning improved whitespace handling The developers of the HTML Parser hope you enjoy it.

I just started looking at HTMLParser yesterday so forgive me if this is an incorrect question. Basically I have a "dirty" HTML document coming out of MS Word 2000 that I need to parse to pull some information from and store in portions of in a database. One of the tags that Word uses throughout is the LinkScanner, LinkTagData classes to become NamedLinkTag, NamedLinkScanner, and NamedLinkTagData as I needed to be able to get the name used for the anchor. I tehn extended the LinkScannerTest class to have 3 tests of my own. The last test looks like this assertTrue("The node should be a named link tag",node[0] instanceof assertEquals("Link Text of link tag","Click This test keeps failing on the parseAndAssertNodeCount(1) method with returning a 3 instead of a 1. What is the likely cause of this? It almost seems as though the <a name=""> is not seen a link (thus a namedlinktag), by the parser? Thanks for your help, Greg

Apologies all, isn't it always the way it works. 2 minutes after sending the email after pulling your hair out all morning you find out the failure was becuase you failed to override a method (in my case evaluateTag). Apologies for the original email. g

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] extract string from a web page which contains <table> ...
mail.body: Hello, first, I'd like to appologize for being idle since last summer but I had = a lot of other works to do. The "quarilis project", a search engine, for which I used HTMLParser, is = in beta status.You can see some information in French about this project on = the web page: http://www.quarilis.org and the link to HTMLParser at http://www.quarilis.org/liens.html . We used HTMLParser to parse and WGET = to crawl but we have in project to let HTMLParser do the whole work. Now, for a month, I have had some time to work for my own. I projected a long time ago to parse web pages from a French tv program website to info= rm me when a series I like is broadcast. I'm really impressed by the progress of the crawler and parser, but I hav= e a problem. This is not a bug but a strange result. When I try to parse http://television.telerama.fr/tv_62.asp?lettre=3DW fo= r example, the result is: [...] Wasteland Lendemain de f=EAte 11:40 sur TF6 Week-end bleu - Spin City Accident de bus 16:25 sur Canal + Bleu Confidences dans un avion 16:45 sur Canal + Bleu La visite du pr=E9sident 16:05 sur Canal + Bleu Le bras droit du maire est amoureux 17:05 sur Canal + Bleu [...] and the HTML code is: [...] ,Helvetica" size=3D"2" color=3D"#000066"><b>Wasteland</b></td></tr><tr><td colspan=3D= 2 width=3D"405"><font face=3DArial,Helvetica size=3D2 color=3D#000066><i>Le= ndemain de ,Helvetica" size=3D"2" color=3D"#000066"><b>Week-end bleu - Spin City</b></td></tr><t= r><td colspan=3D2 width=3D"405"><font face=3DArial,Helvetica size=3D2 [...] Apparently, there isn't a new line with a <tr> if the </tr> is on the sam= e line ? Why not put a carriage return after every <td> and <tr> ? That wa= y, it would be easier to retrieve information. I suggest to have such an output: [...] Wasteland Lendemain de f=EAte 11:40 sur TF6 Week-end bleu - Spin City Accident de bus 16:25 sur Canal + Bleu Confidences dans un avion 16:45 sur Canal + Bleu La visite du pr=E9sident 16:05 sur Canal + Bleu Le bras droit du maire est amoureux 17:05 sur Canal + Bleu [...] I hope you'll appreciate my idea, but if you prefer to let it like this, = can you tell me, please, where I can patch to obtain the result I want (class= es have changed a lot since last summer) ... Regards, Cedric.

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] extract string from a web page which contains <table> ...
mail.body: CÃ©dric, What you want ("\r\n" after each <tr> and <td>) can be done with table handling code similar to the response I gave to Patrick Gamble: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Can the program do this? However, if you want to do it within the current code structure, you would need to override toHtml() in TableRow and TableColumn. Derrick CÃ©dric ROSA wrote: http://www.quarilis.org and the link to HTMLParser at http://www.quarilis.org/liens.html . We used HTMLParser to parse and WGET to http://television.telerama.fr/tv_62.asp?lettre=W for

mail.header: RE: [Htmlparser-user] extract string from a web page which contains <table> ...
mail.body: I really think that having a carriage return put by the parser is a bad idea, since it could distort output and hence affect the display in a browser. Dhaval P.S. In fact I did have a case earlier wherein, due to the parser putting in extra carriage returns during toHtml(), I was getting a distorted output in my browser.

I want to extract regularly updated (from the server side) information = in tables on three single web pages and paste it into a simple matrix, so = that I can=20 compare the changes. I am not a professional programmer, and have been told that my best=20 approach would be Perl and LWP. But I am exploring all options, and having come across Htmlparser, wonder whether it is an alternative=20 approach? Thank you for your help.

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Can the program do this?
mail.body: If you need to dig into tables and get a specific cell, the code you need is something like this: public class Example /** * Example * @param args Pass arg[0] as the URL to process. */ public static void main (String[] args) try parser.setURL (args[0]); /* http://whatever */ while (iterator.hasMoreNodes ()) if (node instanceof BodyTag) for (int h = 0; h < contents.length; h++) if (contents[h] instanceof TableTag) for (int i=0;i<tableTag.getRowCount ();i++) for (int j=0;j<columns.length;j++) // do something with columns[j] // see the HTMLParser API http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/javadoc_1_3/ catch (ParserException pe) Derrick Patrick Gamble wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Htmlparser-user] Initial help with the htmlparser
mail.body: Hello all, Maybe you could help me out with these: I have been studying two books: Web Content Mining with Java and Programing Spiders, bots and Aggregators in Java. Well, I am a Computer Science student and I am very much interested on Java which I am always studying in my free time. I have my own websites that I wrote with PHP. Now, suppose I have two types of situation, a page that I pass an URL with a ?code=23928393 after it, so a GET and I have a page with a table returned. Case number 2 is a page where I need to post the code and get the same table back. Now, what I would like you to teach me is how to write a very simple sample app that either call http://www.someurl.com?code=2382832 and parse the returning page's table to fetch its content one by one and a post to http://www.someurl.com/search.php4 where there is a code text field and a submit button in it. The result is the same page's table that I need to parse. So: 1) Who do I call a URL? Who to do POST and GET? 2) Who do I parse the returning table? Could you help me out teaching me a quick and dirty start? I would apreciate it much. Thanks in advance! regards, Carlos Fernando Scheidecker Antunes.

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Htmlparser-user] Initial help with the htmlparser
mail.body: Hi Antunes, Did you check http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/ ? http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/PostOperation GET requests fall within the default usage. Regards, Somik Sent: Wednesday, May 14, 2003 6:12 PM Subject: [Htmlparser-user] Htmlparser-user] Initial help with the htmlparser http://www.someurl.com?code=2382832 and http://www.someurl.com/search.php4 where there is a code text http://www.enterpriselinuxforum.com https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user
Hi, How do I use the html parser with proxy servers? Can I set the proxy IP and port with: java ... -Dhttp.proxyHost= -Dhttp.proxyPort= Thanks, Steve

This is probably an enhancement request. You could do it yourself though, by passing in a URLConnection you've already got past the proxy. Steve Chen wrote: http://www.enterpriselinuxforum.com https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

I have set up the syncmail script to automatically send email about CVS commit operations to a newly created htmlparser-cvs mailing list. Thus, you can monitor the code repository for bug fixes and enhancements. A new list was chosen over sending to the htmlparser-developer list directly to provide an opt-out mechanism and to keep the traffic light on the htmlparser-developer list. If you want to subscribe to the CVS notification list, go to the lists area: http://sourceforge.net/mail/?group_id=24399 and choose Subscribe/Unsubscribe/Preferences for the htmlparser-cvs list. Derrick

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Why can't the compiler find HTMLParserException?
mail.body: Dmitri, You need to use nearly the same classpath, that you used for compiling, when you run it: javac -classpath htmlparser.jar LinkExtractor.java then java -classpath .;htmlparser.jar LinkExtractor.java The path component (the dot) added on the front, will find the compiled LinkExtractor.class file rather than the one already in the htmlparser.jar file. Derrick Dmitri Rettig wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] HTML Parser Integration Release 1.3-20030504 is out
mail.body: This is the second candidate release for wrapping up version 1.3 and proceeding to version 1.4. Integration Build 1.3 - 20030504 -------------------------------- [1] Fixed bug #728609 - Stack Overflow error. Caused composite tag scanner design to evolve further. Ul-Li scanner relationship can be interesting study model for designing other scanner relationships. [2] Fixed bug #729334 NodeReader::readElement() Null point dereferenced [3] Fixed bug #729368 Embedded quote and split tag [4] Fixed bug #731684 Body and title tags with attributes not parsed This will lead to a change in behaviour, BODY tags with attributes will now have all the html body encapsulated within them as children. If you were handling BODY tags as composite tags before, this shouldn't make any difference.

Hallo i want to use the BodyScanner of your htmlparser in the way to recognize a complex scheme like: <body style="margin-top:4px; margin-left:20px;" How can i do that? At the moment, the scanner recognize only the simple tag <body>. The same problem exists if I want to extract content from a table in the scheme like this: ..... My Code: .... I woud be happy about a fast answer with code example. Greetings Beate -- +++ GMX - Mail, Messaging & more http://www.gmx.net +++ Bitte lÃ¤cheln! Fotogalerie online mit GMX ohne eigene Homepage!

Beate, It turns out that you discovered a bug in the BODY tag processor. For tracking purposes it's #731684 body and title tags with attributes not parsed. I should have it fixed shortly. Regarding your table question, if you just want all the text out of a web page, use something like this: public class GetText /** * GetText * @param args Pass arg[0] as the URL to process. */ public static void main (String[] args) if (0 >= args.length) System.out.println ("Usage: java -classpath htmlparser.jar:. http://whatever_url else But if you need to dig into tables and get a specific cell, the code you need is something like this (when the bug is fixed): public class Example /** * Example * @param args Pass arg[0] as the URL to process. */ public static void main (String[] args) try while (iterator.hasMoreNodes ()) if (node instanceof BodyTag) while (enumeration.hasMoreElements ()) System.out.println (key + ": " + attributes.get for (int h = 0; h < contents.length; h++) if (contents[h] instanceof TableTag) rows = for (int i = 0 ; i < rows.length; i++) if (rows[i] instanceof TableRow) columns = for (int j = 0; j < columns.length; j++) if (columns[j] instanceof TableColumn) cells = cells.length; k++) if (cells[k] instanceof StringNode) System.out.println catch (ParserException pe)
> if (contents[h] instanceof TableTag) columns.length; j++) This can be simplified to: System.out.println(columns.toPlainTextString()); // I think this = line should work =20 Regards, Somik

Hello all, is there some documentation what the filter parameter for scanners means? I noticed some code like: What does that -b mean? What would "" mean? Background: I'm using the htmlparser to index web pages for Apache Lucene and would like to just index text nodes that appear in the body of an HTML document. I read about the StringBean, but that makes a HTTP connection, which is of no use to me, as I read the files locally. My code looks like this: // just collect text nodes in one StringBuffer // treat meta tags specially // treat title tags specially So I tried registering a BodyScanner, but for some reason it never fired. Maybe because I made a mistake in using "" as filter parameter? Thank you very much in advance for any pointers, Ulrich -- Ulrich Mayring DENIC eG, Systementwicklung

> is there some documentation what the filter parameter for scanners You can ignore it- it is mostly for command line usage of the parser. Legacy, and should/would be removed in a later release.. I am not sure if the StringBean cannot handle local files - Derrick Oswald can clarify that.. Looking at your code, it seems like you would benefit with the visitor mechanism - check http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/LinkExtraction , example 3. I also don't think you need a BodyScanner- use that only if you want a big BODY object (if you want a DOM model). Regards, Somik

Somik Raha wrote: http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/LinkExtraction , example 3. I looked at that example before, but it appeared to me it would need more memory and perform worse (please correct me if I'm wrong). To me it looks like the visitor mechanism reads in the whole document and then for each type of node the whole document is traversed in search of the right nodes (DOM style). In my code example I need to traverse the document only once (SAX style) and as I encounter each node I decide what to do with it. Ok, but there is apparently no way to find out for a Node if it is within the body or not. So I thought to wait for the body node to appear and to start extracting strings only then. cheers, Ulrich -- Ulrich Mayring DENIC eG, Systementwicklung

> I looked at that example before, but it appeared to me it would need Nope. It is very much in the SAX style. The document is traversed in real-time - the visitor methods are called as the traversal is progressing. Yes there is. In visitTag(), check if you've recieved the BODY tag (use boolean flags :). Regards, Somik

Somik Raha wrote: Ok, then I misunderstood the example. Another question: in the example it says I can implement my own Visitor by extending Visitor, but there is no such class. Which is the class I should extend, maybe NodeVisitor or ObjectFindingVisitor? Also, what is the difference between the recurseSelf and recurseChildren parameters? So the way it works is: - for every encountered tag the method visitTag() is called - for every encountered title tag the method visitTitleTag() is called - etc? cheers, Ulrich -- Ulrich Mayring DENIC eG, Systementwicklung

Ulrich, Yes, NodeVisitor is the one to extend, unless you just want to extend the functionality of one of the other derived classes. For composite tags, if the visitors recurse children is true the children of the tag are visited. If the visitors recurse self is true, the tag itself is visited after the children are visited. The org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean class is an example of a visitor implementation. Derrick Ulrich Mayring wrote:

Yes, this is what I'm using the library for. I am parsing input HTML = with custom scanners looking for "custom" tags that I've created. It = then turns those tags into dynamic javascript. All other HTML on the = page is left as-is. The result is a page that functions exactly the = same, only with the extra dynamic javascript that was created. The only obvious side effect, if you look at the output, is that since = the htmlparser does not preserve the case of tags and attributes, it = will UPPER CASE everything. You can do that by: // do your processing here HTH. Regards, Somik

I HTML parser complete enough that you can use it to parse incoming HTML, and write a new outgoing HTML file (with or without changes to the content) such that the outgoing HTML renders the same as the incoming HTML would have rendered?

Does htmlparser support different charsets such as Shift_JIS and Big5? That is, if the meta tag in the HTML file is can one tell htmlparser to read text in the charset? or convert the charset to Unicode? Gil

Gil, The support is there, although a guy named Steve had some trouble with a "GB2312"(chinese encoding) because the java.nio.charset.Charset doesn't support it. The parser first sets the charset according to the charset specified in the HTTP header. It then prescans the header looking for a charset directive in the HTML page and resets to the new charset if it's different. One of the testcases is to fetch " http://www.ibm.com/jp/ " and ensure the charset is correctly set to Shift_JIS, although no attempt is made to ensure the resultant text is correct. None of us knows Japanese. Derrick Gil Hansen wrote: http://www.etnus.com . https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

I would like to build a DOM style access to my parsed HTML. Currently if I use extractAllNodesThatAre(Html.class), then try to do a extractAllNodesThatAre(TablTag.class) iteration, I get an empty list. I've tried hacking recreateReader() to public, pending a proper wrapping method. But then the NodeList comes as different objects to the previous parse. i) Is there any way to reset the parser 'cursor'? ii) Perhaps overriding the equals() in a Node is in order? Each tag can be uniquely identified by a Vector of parent tags and offset from said parent tag. Thus Node a.equals(b) could be driven from the path back to the root node? a Java equivalent to WebL, which is a Modula2 derivative. [ http://research.compaq.com/SRC/WebL/library.html ] Then HtmlParser would really start to shine. WebL is a bit too heavy, and doesn't run on JVMs more modern than 1.1! Terry. ===== ------------------------------------------------------------ Terry Alexis Lurie | 'Something witty that doesn't Freelance Computer Engineer | look good with variable United Kingdom | width fonts' - Most nerds __________________________________________________ Yahoo! Plus - For a better Internet experience http://uk.promotions.yahoo.com/yplus/yoffer.html

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Traversing the tree multiple times
mail.body: Terry, Could you gather all the top level nodes into a NodeList once, and then run your extracts against that? The code in Parser to do the extraction is pretty simple: public Node [] extractAllNodesThatAre(Class nodeType) throws ParserException for (NodeIterator e = elements(); e.hasMoreNodes();) so your code would be: public Node [] extractAllNodesThatAre(NodeList topLevel, Class nodeType) for (NodeIterator e = topLevel.elements(); e.hasMoreNodes();) Derrick Terry Alexis Lurie wrote: http://research.compaq.com/SRC/WebL/library.html ]

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Traversing the tree multiple times

Hi guys, thanks for all yor help so far. I have experienced this from the beginning, but I've always found a work around so far. Now I am at my wits end. When I parse a Google result page, HtmlParser gets the parse wrong. I have visually eyeballed the html, to make sure. What I've found, is that when a <TABLE> node is returned, the Node 'leaks' out into further HTML, beyond the </TABLE> closing. I do have examples, and I can post code, but I have a deadline, so I thought I would test the waters to see if there is a quick solution. At first there were completely wrong results, and I fixed that by not calling registerDomScanners(). Instead I cut&pasted what this equated to into my own code, and commented out most of the scanners I didn't need. This was fine. But now I discover that on some Google pages an advertisers box (TABLE) is inserted, and the TABLE leak/runover problem causes my code to barf. This is driving me mad, and I don't have the time to step-by-step through the HtmlParser to see where it is failing. I have tried the 1_4 release as well, which didn't fair any better. Thanks, this is a repeatable verifiable error, but perhaps I'm missing something? Terry. ===== ------------------------------------------------------------ Terry Alexis Lurie | 'Something witty that doesn't Freelance Computer Engineer | look good with variable United Kingdom | width fonts' - Most nerds __________________________________________________ Yahoo! Plus - For a better Internet experience http://uk.promotions.yahoo.com/yplus/yoffer.html

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Re: Scanning for input tags doesn't work! Bug?
mail.body: Derrick Oswald wrote: http://www.student.informatik.tu-darmstadt.de appears to be offline Thanks in advance! The site had some problems, it should work now. Christian.
Hello! Could somebody confirm that this is a bug? Thanks! :-) Christian.

Hi Christian, The form tag contains the contents you want, but it's buried within the table tag: Search: The form scanner extends the CompositeScanner which blindly gathers up the tags inside, so you get a couple of StringNodes and a TableTag. The FormTag constructor code was performing a searchFor() the input and textarea tags but wasn't doing it recursively. I've added code to the NodeList class to do that now. In case you want to check out the files before the next integration build, the files affected are org/htmlparser/tags/FormTag.java org/htmlparser/util/NodeList.java I also added getFormTextAreas() to FomTag so you can get all the textarea tags. Derrick Christian Janoff wrote:

hi all, I just tried using the htmlparser library, I'm using 1.3. I'm = trying to parse a page that contains an image tag like img src=3D"...", = I used the following code: 1.however, none of the nodes are an instance of the ImageTag, what's = wrong? =20 2.Ultimately I need to modify the image tags embedded in some html = String. However UrlModifyingVisitor does not do what I want because it = prepends only, I need more than prepending. I need to take the filename = without any parent path and then prepend it with some prefix path. how = can this be done? thanks a million -jonathan

http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/ImageExtraction Try registering just the ImageScanner - so embedded Image tags will not = pose a problem (unless you need link tags as well). The other way is to write your own visitor - all visitors have a = visitImageTag() method. You can then do, parser.visitAllNodesWith(visitor) Regards, Somik From: jonathan zhang=20 To: htmlparser-user@... However UrlModifyingVisitor does not do what I want because it = prepends only, I need more than prepending. I need to take the filename = without any parent path and then prepend it with some prefix path. how = can this be done? thanks a million -jonathan

thanks a lot Somik, I tried register with just the ImageScanner and it worked. But = registerAllScanners supposedly register the ImageScanners along with = others, so is this a bug? regards, -jonathan From: Somik Raha=20 To: htmlparser-user@... Sent: Tuesday, July 29, 2003 5:03 PM Subject: Re: [Htmlparser-user] ImageTag not recognized http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/docs/index.php/ImageExtraction Try registering just the ImageScanner - so embedded Image tags will = not pose a problem (unless you need link tags as well). You can then do, parser.visitAllNodesWith(visitor) Regards, Somik From: jonathan zhang=20 To: htmlparser-user@... However UrlModifyingVisitor does not do what I want because it = prepends only, I need more than prepending. I need to take the filename = without any parent path and then prepend it with some prefix path. how = can this be done? thanks a million -jonathan

No - embedded images are found, but they are embedded within the = appropriate object. So if an image is within a link, you will find a = LinkTag object containing an ImageTag under it. When you want both links = and images, you need to use the visitor approach. If not, go with = registering only the Image Scanner - that will treat all tags except = images generically. Regards, Somik From: jonathan zhang=20 To: htmlparser-user@... The other way is to write your own visitor - all visitors have a = visitImageTag() method. Sunil, Oops, yes that's an omission from the zip. It's just some third party libraries from junit.org and ant.apache.org that were incorporated in Sunday's release. The build.xml file was supposed to exclude the lexer package, but I forgot the wildcards (...lexer/**). The lexer package isn't needed at the moment. I've posted a new htmlparser1_4_20030727.zip that has the lib/ directory. It's file size is 2181747 bytes. I'll fix the build.xml file too. mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Two attributes style in one tag
mail.body: Yes, indeed, I think this is one of the most important of the goals for the new i/o subsystem I'm working on. From org.htmlparser.lexer.package.html: The following are some design goals and 'invariants' within the package, if you are attempting to understand or modify it. Things that differ substantially from previous implementations are highlighted in *bold*. Contiguous Nodes *Adjacent nodes have no characters between them.* The list of nodes forms an uninterrupted chain that, by start and end definitions, completely covers the characters that were read from the HTML source. Despite this, the nodes are not stored in a linked list, but rather an array to ease any editing tasks that may be performed. Text Fidelity Besides complete coverage, the *nodes do not contain copies of the text*, but instead simply contain offsets into a single large buffer that contains the text read from the HTML source. Even within tags, the attributes list can contain whitespace, thus there is no lost whitespace or text formatting either outside or within tags. Upper and lower case text is preserved. Line Endings *End of line characters are just whitespace.* There is no distinction made between end of line characters (or pairs of characters on Windows) and other whitespace. The text is not read in line by line so nodes (tags) can easily span multiple lines with no special processing. Line endings are not transformed between platforms, i.e. Unix line endings are not converted to Windows line endings by this level. Each node will has a starting and ending location, which the page can use to extract the text. To facilitate formatting error and log messages the page can turn these offsets into row and column numbers. In general ignore line breaks in the source if at all possible. One Parser, One Scan The Lexer has the following state machines corresponding (roughly) to the *four parsers it replaces* (StringParser, RemarkNodeParser, # TagParser & AttributeParser): in text - parseString() # in comment - parseRemark() # in tag - parseTag() By integrating the four state machines into one, a single pass over the text is all that's needed for a low level parse of the HTML source. In previous implementations, the attributes were parsed on a second scan after the initial tag was extracted. Two Jars For elementary operations at the node level, a minimalist jar file containing *only the lexer and base tag classes* is split out from the larger |htmlparser.jar|. In this way, simple parsing and output is handled with a jar file that is under 40 kilobytes, but anything beyond peephole manipulation, i.e. closing tag detection and other semantic reasoning, will need the full set of scanners, nodes and ancillary classes, which now stands at 160 kilobytes. I don't think the formatting of the above will make it through the list mangler but you can get it yourself from CVS if you can't read it here. Derrick Marc Novakowski wrote:

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Two attributes style in one tag
mail.body: Costa, The storage of attributes in a Hashtable by name, would preclude getting any more than one of them (the last). I'm working on another way to store attributes, in a Vector. The new toHtml() method honours the three attributes of the same name. It also has the ability to access duplicates like this via a replacement for the getAttributes() method called getAttributesEx(), which currently returns the vector rather than a Hashtable. The getAttribute() method which returns only one string is more problematic. Until then (htmlparser version 1.4), I'm afraid there is no way to retain or get at the first two style attributes, sorry. Derrick Costa Andres wrote:

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Getting Node values and deciding which nodes to get
mail.body: C.F. You can ues instanceof to detect what type it is and then cast it: if (list.elementAt(k) instanceof StringNode) Similarly for the other classes RemarkNode and Tag. Tag, of course, has many subclasses, like LinkTag. To see the subclasses you are getting, try: The 'begin' and 'end' values reflect where the text or tag lies in the original HTML stream on a line. In the case of multiple lines (like your's looks like) it may not be so useful, and you certainly can't 'control' where it begins and ends. I would ignore this. I should have originally advised you to use toPlainTextString() instead of toString(). Derrick C.F. Scheidecker Antunes wrote:

I am new to java, I downloaded Html parser form sourceforge and copy the org folder and its sub-folder into my program folder, and then try copy a sample program from htmlparser`s homepage, as shown below, but when try to compile it, it give me error says StringExtractor.java:31: package org.htmlparser.beans does not exist ^ StringExtractor.java:32: package org.htmlparser.util does not exist ^ StringExtractor.java:54: cannot resolve symbol symbol : class ParserException location: class org.htmlparser.parserapplications.StringExtractor ParserException ^ StringExtractor.java:56: cannot resolve symbol symbol : class StringBean location: class org.htmlparser.parserapplications.StringExtractor where should I put the org folder? Paul ====================================================

Paul, It looks like a package problem. You need to maintain the directory structure exactly, don't just copy it into your program folder (unless you aren't using a package). The org directory should exist side by side with your top level package directory. Derrick Paul Lin wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] How do I extract the text from a column?
mail.body: Hello all, If I issue the following command: it will print on the screen something like this: Begin Tag : td bgcolor = #ccffff width="4%" align="left" valign="top" height="2"; begins at : 8; ends at : 42 If I do a column[i].getText() I get the following: td bgcolor = #ccffff width="7%" align="center" valign="top" height="2" My question is: How do I extract the actual content of a cell? In the first row cell I have on the first column: Name, second Alfred, Rich, third Thomas, Carl and so on. I would like to extract the values between <td> and </td> how can I do that? Thanks in advance. C.F.

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] How do I extract the text from a column?
mail.body: C.F. It depends on what's in the column, what type of 'values' you'll get. Could be just text or links or forms etc. The contents will be in the children (it's a CompositeTag) so one of SimpleNodeIterator(), getChild(), getChildrenAsNodeArray() or getChildren() should be used to get at the Node objects that are contained within the column, i.e. for (int i = 0; i < list.size; i++) Derrick C.F. mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Help - how to get the text within different tag ?
mail.body: Your first example indicates you want to trigger text collection after a all text after that. Subclass org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean and override visitStringNode() and visitEndTag(). Look for a tag name of "BIG" and set a flag to start collecting text only then: public class MyBean extends StringBean ... public void visitStringNode (StringNode string) if (triggered) public void visitEndTag (EndTag end) if (end.getTagName ().equals ("BIG")) Derrick yopllit wrote:

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Marking areas to be ignored for string extraction

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Marking areas to be ignored for string extraction
mail.body: Joe, I think you would need to subclass StringBean and override 'visitTag ()' with something like: void visitTag (Tag tag) if (isMySpecialCommentTag (tag)) else with similar code in 'visitEndTag ()' to turn off the flag. Then handle the flag (i.e. override visitStringNode ()) in methods that need to do something different. Derrick Joe.A.Silvagni@... wrote:

mail.body: I am having a problem using the HTMLParser environment and wondered if anyone in this group had any pointers to places where I might go and find answers. My specific problem is that in some of the HTML that I am using, the code contains a large number of the special characters (egg those starting &# and terminating with a semicolon egg &#114; I haven't found an easy way of decoding those things into their text representations short of examining the returned string from aStringNode.getText(). I am sure that someone somewhere must have done this before - low level String manipulation is so tedious. If there is code in the HTMLParser package's) and I have missed it, I apologize for taking up people's valuable time. Thanks in advance Regards Chris Bird I guess if the code doesn't exist I am honor bound to write it and post the results! C

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Handling text in its various representations.
mail.body: Chris, I recently integrated code to configure the parser to decode strings. To use it, do the following: * instantiate org.htmlparser.StringNodeFactory and set its shouldDecodeNodes(true). * instantiate the parser and set its StringNodeFactory by calling setStringNodeFactory(...). * begin parsing by iterating through the nodes or using a TextExtractVisitor to obtain the text you need. -jk Christopher Bird wrote: http://aspnet.click-url.com/go/psa00100003ave/direct;at.aspnet_072303_01/01 https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Handling text in its various representations.
mail.body: Christopher, If you want explicit conversion of a String, look at the static method org.htmlparser.util.Translate.decode (). Derrick Christopher Bird wrote: http://aspnet.click-url.com/go/psa00100003ave/direct;at.aspnet_072303_01/01 https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.body: Hi Derrick, I am trying to analyse Java Documentation via Parser. I want to do the following: 1- Visit the root URL (i.e. http://htmlparser.sourceforge.net/javadoc_1_3/ ) 2- Find links on the root URL and add to the root List. 3- Visit first/next URL on root List & collect corresponding child links in a object Array. (NodeList) 4- Visit the child Links List and repeat the process from Step 1, in a breadth first search manner. I have managed to do the step 1-2 and 3 but I am having difficulty in step 4. When I run the program, parser identifies the links but the order the links are visited and output is wrong. mail.body: Hello all, I have two questions. First is when I am using an URLConnection object I can set the User Agent so that in the webservers it will show as being an Internet Explorer Borwser. I can do a Windows NT 5.0)") with URLConnection. How could I do the same when using the HTMLParser classes to extract a page with a Parser object? Can I pass a URLConnection to it? Or how could I do it? My second question is: How could I extract the contents between the <pre> and </pre> tags? I have been doing it mannually and I would like to know if it would be possible to do such thing with HTMLParser. Thanks in advance.

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] User Agent and how to parse <pre>
mail.body: You can pass a fully conditioned URLConnection object to the parser via the setConnection() call. R.T.F.M. Using the visitor pattern, you extend NodeVisitor and override at least visitTag() and visitEndTag() watching for the <PRE> and </PRE>. Other overrides from NodeVisitor depend on what you want to extract. See StringBean for an example. C.F. Scheidecker Antunes wrote:

hi Derick Thanks for the reply, but , seems like when I use as you suggested below , I get only corrupted ("?") characters instead of japanese characters , is there a way to prevent this? Thanks in advance Kerem -----Original Message----- From: htmlparser-user-admin@... [mailto:htmlparser-user-admin@... Behalf Of Derrick Oswald Sent: Thursday, July 31, 2003 8:57 PM To: htmlparser-user@... Subject: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Encoding problems Kareme You should use just: The new String you're forming from bytes uses the platform's default charset. But you already had a String before turning it into bytes and then you turn it back into a String again. Derrick kerem balik wrote: ------------------------------------------------------- This SF.Net email sponsored by: Free pre-built ASP.NET sites including Data Reports, E-commerce, Portals, and Forums are available now. Download today and enter to win an XBOX or Visual Studio .NET. http://aspnet.click-url.com/go/psa00100003ave/direct;at.aspnet_072303_01/01 _______________________________________________ Htmlparser-user mailing list Htmlparser-user@... https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

Kerem, I don't think I can help much. Take it one step at a time. If you changed the default charset you must have a development environment in order to recompile it. First, check the what encoding the InputStreamReader is really using after it's created by dumping the output of getEncoding() at the end of Parser.createInputStreamReader(): If that's OK, check the incoming characters in NodeReader.getNextLine(). Depending on your environment, this should probably show correct characters: If that's OK, enclose the HTML text in <pre></pre> and see if it's getting messed up by Decode(). ... Other than that, you'll have to debug it I'm afraid. Derrick kerem balik wrote:
Jonathan, The only side effect would be things that were quoted won't be anymore. Some rework is needed in storing the 'exact html' in the attributes list. Derrick jonathan zhang wrote:
I'm trying to retrieve only the selected option value/text from the that, does anyone know how can I retrieved the selected <option>?

I suspect this is a pretty basic question but I couldn't find anything in the archives or the doc. I am building a tool used to 'fix up' the html generated by MS Word with the ultimate destination being a JavaHelp file. Among other things, one of the things I want to do is remove the embedded style sheet and insert a <link> tag to an external style sheet. The approach I am using is to initially parse the document into a NodeList and then I iterate over the list with a NodeVisitor for each of the various things I want to do to the document. This approach has generally worked great. I can find the <head> tag using this technique and then look at the children and remove the embedded style sheet without a problem. However, I am have difficulty determining how to manufacture a <link> tag as a Tag object relatively easily. If I could do this I could then add it as a child to the head. Finally, after I have done all of my cleanup I could iterate over all of the nodes one last time to create the new html. Any thoughts on how to generate the Thanks for the help

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Building New Tags to Output
mail.body: Thought I would post what I ended up using as my solution. Both just to document it and to seek if anyone just plain thinks it is a bad idea. I found in one of the test cases places where HTML string fragments were defined in the code and then parsed. So, what I ended up doing is building the link tag that I wanted (looked something like <LINK HREF="/mystylsheet.css" REL="stylesheet" TYPE="text/css"> and then parsing that using the Parser.createParser(String) method. This just seemed more obvious what what going on than trying to figure out how to construct a tag on your own. I then find the <LINK> tag and add it as a child to the <HEAD> tag in the document I am modifying. BTW - I find the reference to the <A> tag as a LinkTag little misleading since there is an actual <LINK> tag. I know the <A> tag is commonly referred to as a link but.... I probably wouldn't have thought about it if I had not been interested in inserting a <LINK> tag. Great library. Keep up the good work! Derrick Oswald wrote: irc://server/channel","","",false,false ) http://thinkgeek.com/sf https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

Xue-Feng, The URL 'error' you mention is actually just the way the Java URL class works. Without a terminating slash, the document base URL is assumed to be a resource, which is correctly removed by the algorithm. Here's an example: public class UrlProblem public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException docbase = new URL (" http://cbc.ca/business docbase = new URL (" http://cbc.ca/business/ // output: // http://cbc.ca/quotes.html // http://cbc.ca/business/quotes.html This is why most URL's that reference the default document (usually index.html), end in a slash. Xue-Feng, They may resolve to the same document in any browser, but the server is performing the conversion, usually by adding index.html, even if it doesn't indicate it. Try this little experiment: Type http://www.cbc.ca/index.html into your browser. It works. Why? because the server converts both http://www.cbc.ca and http://www.cbc.ca/ into the same reference, namely http://www.cbc.ca/index.html which it then sends to your browser. If you think it would accept anything, try typing http://www.cbc.ca/bogus.html - it won't work. Now type http://www.cbc.ca/business/index.html into your browser. It doesn't work. Why? Because the http://www.cbc.ca/business or http://www.cbc.ca/business/ does not get converted into that, but instead reference an unknown page, maybe even a jsp page or whatever. On the client side, we cannot know that http://www.cbc.ca/business really refers to http://www.cbc.ca/business/local_cbc_portal.jsp or whatever. It must be assumed that the last element, unless it ends with a slash, is the file name and hence it must be removed to resolve relative references. This is the correct behaviour. It is not a bug. Check out the unit tests in utilTests.HTMLLinkProcessorTest and it's reference documentation: // // Tests from Appendix C Examples of Resolving Relative URI References // RFC 2396 Uniform Resource Identifiers (URI): Generic Syntax // T. Berners-Lee et al. // http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt Derrick Xue-Feng Yang wrote: http://cbc.ca/business/ " and http://cbc.ca/business " have the same meaning for http://cbc.ca/business/quotes.html http://cbc.ca/quotes.html http://cbc.ca/business1/business2/.../businessn/ ". http://cbc.ca/business1/business2/.../business(n-1)/quotes.html

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Lower Case vs. Upper Case tags / attributes
mail.body: I have noticed that the output from the parser when you use the toHtml() method changes all of the tags / attributes keys to upper case. I have not seen in the java docs any way to get the output to either keep the original case or to change all to lower case. My under standing is the xhtml requires all of the tags to be in lower case. Are there any plans for adding an option to the parser / tags to change the case of the tags to lower case? Or is there a way to do this that I am just not seeing? Thanks

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Lower Case vs. Upper Case tags / attributes
mail.body: The default behavior is implemented in AttributeParser (if I'm not mistaken). This parser aims at allowing you to parse dirty html quick and fast. Not intended as an html cleaner, or xhtml producer. However, if lower case attribute names help you - then it could be a feature request. The only big work is the modification of all tests that break (which is not much). Would you be willing to volunteer? Regards, Somik --- Mark Ault <mark.ault@...> wrote: ------------------------------------------------------- http://thinkgeek.com/sf https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? The New Yahoo! Shopping - with improved product search http://shopping.yahoo.com

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Lower Case vs. Upper Case tags / attributes
mail.body: Mark, That's a good use-case we'll try to incorporate going forward.. As it stands though, there isn't any code* to convert the tags and attributes to lower case. Sorry. Derrick * as far as I'm aware of anyway Mark Ault wrote:

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Lower Case vs. Upper Case tags / attributes
mail.body: Let me get a dev environment set up for htmlParser and yes I would be willing to take a stab at it. I may need a little assistance getting things set up to talk to cvs on sourceforge since I am a relatively novice CVS user but I will contact you outside of this list for that. Mark Somik Raha wrote: http://thinkgeek.com/sf https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user http://shopping.yahoo.com http://thinkgeek.com/sf https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Parsed HTML to XML for use with XSLT?
mail.body: I hope this isn't too naive a question, but has anyone used html parser to implement an HTML->XML transformation system? My goal is to be able to parse legacy HTML pages with an XSLT-based parser... regards, David

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Parsed HTML to XML for use with XSLT?
mail.body: Yep. This project is definitely heading in a nice direction for this sort of thing. The 'tidy' program barfs [excuse my French] a bit to easily for my liking. You will find yourself re-implementing the HTML DTD, with lots of exceptions to clean up where the source HTML is broken. Um, also check out Compaq WebL, which despite the 1999 finish date is very good at handling broken HTML wisely. http://research.compaq.com/SRC/WebL . It requires JRE 1.1, to work. Its based on Pascal/Modula 2, but it has powerful manipulation constructs. Terry. --- David HM Spector <spector@...> wrote: > I hope this isn't too naive a question, but has anyone used html parser http://thinkgeek.com/sf https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/htmlparser-user ===== ------------------------------------------------------------ Terry Alexis Lurie | 'Something witty that doesn't Freelance Computer Engineer | look good with variable United Kingdom | width fonts' - Most nerds ________________________________________________________________________ Want to chat instantly with your online friends? Get the FREE Yahoo! Messenger http://mail.messenger.yahoo.co.uk

Hi all Is it possible to make multiply calls of function extractAllNodesThatAre ? The parser.elements() are parsed only once, and i can not see any function to restart node iterations. Examlpe: first println prints some nummber like 600, second 0. Thanks Juris

Juris, [this is a repeat of a previous message titled "Traversing the tree multiple times"] Could you gather all the top level nodes into a NodeList once, and then run your extracts against that? The code in Parser to do the extraction is pretty simple: public Node [] extractAllNodesThatAre(Class nodeType) throws ParserException for (NodeIterator e = elements(); e.hasMoreNodes();) so your code would be: public Node [] extractAllNodesThatAre(NodeList topLevel, Class nodeType) for (NodeIterator e = topLevel.elements(); e.hasMoreNodes();) Derrick Juris Zubkans wrote:

Hi Somik and all it has been a long time since I did not post here, and I kind a forgot some of the things I did with htmlparser. Today I was back to my program to do a small test. I could not read this page because it contains if I remove "charset=windows-1252", then I can open and read the file. Would you give me a hint on this, so I could open and read the page that has such a meta tag? Thanks Navid __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! SiteBuilder - Free, easy-to-use web site design software http://sitebuilder.yahoo.com

Hi Navid, There is code in the Parser class to detect charset directives, both in the HTTP response header and the HTML content itself. Sometimes they disagree. It then backs up and retraces the file with the new charset. If the page comes from a file it assumes ISO-8859-1 until it encounters the meta tag. If this isn't working can you file a bug with the failing page. Is there feedback saying 'detected charset "XXX", using "YYY"'? Derrick Navid H.Langaroudi wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Question on inserting spaces at end of line...
mail.body: I am using the HTMLParser to extract the display text portion of a website so it can be indexed and stored in a database for our search engine. The parser works fine but each line of text that wraps needs to have a space included, otherwise it shows as one large word. For example: My text goes here and since the sentence is rather long it will wrap. When I extract the text I get: My text goes here and since the sentence is rather longit will wrap. I need to get the space between long and it. Below is the code snippet I'm using to parse the text: String url =3D " http://127.0.0.1/ ... pageText =3D Any help would be greatly appreciated. Best Regards, Tommy E. Cole, Jr. General Manager & C.O.O. Lamatek, Inc. tcole@... http://www.lamatek.com=20

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Question on inserting spaces at end of line...
mail.body: Tom, The StringExtractingVisitor is very simplistic and does no whitespace collapsing or text flow break processing. So not only will it jam all the strings together higgledy-piggledy, but there won't be newlines where there should be and possibly lots of extra space where there shouldn't be. I pefer the StringBean to get text, probably because I wrote it ;). java -classpath htmlparser.jar org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean example.html My text goes here and since the sentence is rather long it will wrap. or java -classpath htmlparser.jar org.htmlparser.parserapplications.StringExtractor example.html My text goes here and since the sentence is rather long it will wrap. See the mainline in either of those classes for ideas. Derrick Tom E. Cole wrote: http://127.0.0.1/ http://www.lamatek.com

I am usiing html parser to parse the files. However the parser accepts the files only that ones that are on the server ie online. I need to parse some files that are on disk . Can somebody tell me how to parse the files that are on disk. The parser object aceepts the input of the form .. Parser parser = new Parser(" http://www.yahoo.com",new i want the first argument to be a location on the disk , but the parser wont work. Can anybody help ?? - Vihang

vihang, The constructor you mention tries first as a URL and then if that fails it tries as a file on the local disk, so new Parser ("d:\\myfile.html", new DefaultParserFeedback()) will work. I see you are using an old version (that uses DefaultHTMLParserFeedback). Try upgrading. Derrick vihang wrote: http://www.yahoo.com",new

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Parser unable to parse attributes if an empty value attribute exi sts
mail.body: Hi, I am trying to parse <applet> tags in HTML.My code looks like following: // add applet tag scanner for (NodeIterator i = parser.elements();i.hasMoreNodes();) if (node instanceof AppletTag) It fails to detect <applet> attributes found after an attribute with empty string value. For example : In this case parser will not be able to detect 'width' and 'height' attributes (as they occur after empty 'archive' attribute). Did anybody came across such problem, and is there any workaround for this. Your response is highly appreciated. Thanks Vikram

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Parser unable to parse attributes if an empty value attribute exi sts
mail.body: Vikram, This is logged as bug #805598 attribute src in tag img sometimes not correctly parsed http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=805598&group_id=24399&atid=381399 which is a duplicate of bug #778781 SRC-attribute suppression in IMG-tags http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=778781&group_id=24399&atid=381399 ...sorry, the reason it's not being attended to is that this problem is obviated by the new lexer code added recently. This will take another few weeks to release though, unless you want to grab the latest snapshot from CVS. Derrick Vikram Mehta wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] How to get images in script
mail.body: Hi All: When there are tags inside script ( such as : Java Script , ASP = , PHP , etc ). How can I get this image?? Below is my code Parser parser =3D new Parser( http://urlIWantToParse.com However , this code doesn't handle Java Script , how can I do that , Thanks in advance

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] How to get images in script
mail.body: I'm guessing here, but... You might be able to send the contents of the script tag through another parser, looking for image tags. You can subclass NodeVisitor and override the visitTag() method to look for script tags, visitAllNodesWith(yourclass). When you find one, you can get it's contents and extract all image nodes from that. Derrick é»ƒæ–‡å‚‘ wrote: http://urlIWantToParse.com

Hi there My names is Ayhan. I have to thank you first for this fantastic product. I have been trying to write a searchengine for turkish sites only and i needed a robot and htmlparser. And your product-htmlparser solved all my problems. However I have a simple problem: I modified your robot.java class and it works fine. My problem is extracting the strippedtext from the page. I wrote my own visitor by extending NodeVisitor. But the text i can collect is full of javascript. I dont want to collect the javascript and the other things. I want to collect the clean text as you can you collect with( TextExtractingVisitor visitor = new TextExtractingVisitor();). I believe the code in org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean extracts the text without javascript. Look at it's code for the visitor methods to override or maybe just use it as is. Derrick Ayhan Peker wrote:

Balz, I presume you don't have a wml scanner, so these would come out as undifferentiated tags. If this is done on a pass through the nodes with the iterator, it would be something lile: while (iterator.hasMoreNodes ()) if (node instanceof Tag && node.getTagName ().equals ("WML")) do if (!(node instanceof EndTag && node.getTagName().equals ("WML")) else else Then you would use your node list to do whatever you want. mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] comments in javascript with quotes inside
mail.body: Hi all, I'm new to htmlparser but I appreciated it very much. I'm coming from JTidy and I definitively decided to change for = htmlparser. Now I've a problem... I'm using htmlparser 1.4 (htmlparser1_4_20031109.zip) I have a script tag like this in a page I'm parsing: // comment with a quote ' I registered a ScriptScanner because I'm interested in avoiding script = text (I'm using htmlparser for text extraction). I didn't use Parser.registerScanners() or any other scanner. When I parse a page with the script tag as before and the ScriptScanner = is registered, the parser stops in corrispondence of the script tag = containing the commented single quote. No more processing is made and no = more text is extracted from the document. I noticed the same behavior = with a single "double-quote". All comes back to normality if I double the single or the double quote = (from ' to '' or from " to "") or I avoid to register the=20 ScriptScanner. In my opinion, it is like the ScriptScanner ignores the script comments = (//) and therefore processes the quotes as a script's "uncommented" = element. When it founds the opening quote and not the closing one it = stops processing nodes in the page. For example this tag let the page be parsed correctly (2 single-quotes = instead of one of the first example): // comment with a quote '' This problem doesn't appear if i don't register a ScriptParser. Someone noticed this strange behavior? can someone help me? If needed I can also send the small code that shows the problem and the = small HTML page I used for testing (very few lines). I will appreciate any help (and sorry for my bad english!) Regards, Andrea

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] comments in javascript with quotes inside
mail.body: Andrea, The difference between the script scanner and regular scanner is that it tries to balance quotes. That is, for script like: it is supposed to ignore the </script> tag within quotes, yet honour the one outside of the quotes. You've run into the case where a single quote is within a comment, but no corresponding end quote exists. At this point the script scanner isn't cognizant of comments, so it assumes the quoted text extends to the end of input. Handling this case could be added, but it would require an augmented or different state machine. We would like to encourage you to write a scanner that can handle these cases (and while you are at it can you write a JSP scanner too?). Until then, if you don't register the script scanner, you should be able to avoid the script text by ignoring elements between the start and end script tag, as long as you don't run into an example like the above. Derrick andrea sponziello wrote:

mail.header: [Htmlparser-user] Adding spaces after tags with TextExtractingVisitor
mail.body: I'm using HtmlParser to turn HTML documents into plain text versions for use with Lucene. My current method is to use TextExtractingVisitor to produce the text version. However, it oftens produces files without sufficient breaks between text, and so you can end up with words being run together My simple solution (patch attached) was to allow you to tell TextExtractingVisitor to add spaces for you, after handling non blank node texts. It does sometimes add extra spaces, but that seems to be better than not adding enough! Is this the right place to attack this problem, or should I be putting space adding code somewhere else? On a different note - has anyone been able to build HtmlParser with Ant 1.5.4? When I try, it breaks, with the last few lines produced: [echo] Replacing version VERSION_DATE = "Oct 26, 2003" with VERSION_DATE = "Nov 05, 2003" in src/org/htmlparser/Parser.java [echo] Replacing version "1.4 (Integration Build Oct 26, 2003)" with "1.4 (Integration Build Nov 05, 2003)" in docs/release.txt [echo] Replacing version tag 1_4_20031026 with 1_4_20031105 in all source files BUILD FAILED file:/usr/local/Java/htmlparser1_4/build.xml:170: IOException in /usr/local/Java/htmlparser1_4/src/org/htmlparser/tests/nodeDecoratorTests/DecodingNodeTest.java - sun.io.MalformedInputException:null Anyone know the solution? Thanks Nick

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Adding spaces after tags with TextExtractingVisitor
mail.body: For better line breaks, try the org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean, it produces text with breaks where most browsers place them, by checking breaksFlow(): java -classpath htmlparser.jar org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean http://whatever_url It's likely the problem with DecodingNodeTest is only the first of a few, having to do with non-ascii characters in the file. I recently fixed this in the CVS trunk, but if you wanted to fix the source you have, run the offending file(s) through native2ascii, which is a utility that comes with the JDK to convert native characters to unicode. I'm not sure how to do it in Windows, but in unix land you set your LANG environment variable to us_EN and run native2ascii DecodingNodeTest.java > temp.txt mv temp.txt DecodingNodeTest.java If you can't get that to work, edit the file(s) manually to remove the division signs and replace them with \u00f7. Derrick Nick Burch wrote:

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Adding spaces after tags with TextExtractingVisitor
mail.body: On Wed, 5 Nov 2003, Derrick Oswald wrote: http://whatever_url That looks close to what I want However, it assumes you'll be using it to do the parsing, not calling it as a standard NodeVisitor from your own parser. If you do call it externally, it barfs with a null pointer, since mBuffer is unset. I think the solution will be to move some of the duplicated init code from extractStrings() and setStrings() into the constructor, and add a new boolean for "has undergone some parsing", which can be the internal check for needing to do the parsing itself. I'll email the patch once I get something sane working native2ascii -reverse did the trick, thanks Nick

mail.header: Re: [Htmlparser-user] Adding spaces after tags with TextExtractingVisitor
mail.body: On Wed, 12 Nov 2003, Nick Burch wrote: http://whatever_url Attached is a patch for org.htmlparser.beans.StringBean, which allows it to be called as a NodeVisitor from a Parser you control, rather than using StringBean's own one. This is handy if you don't want StringBean to wander off and get the content itself, either because you already have it, it's not on a website etc. My testing seems to indicate it shouldn't have broken the previous opperation, so should be safe to apply Nick

Two questions for users and developers... As part of the refactoring going on, the scanners are being obviated. This means that except for the TagScanner, CompositeTagScanner and ScriptScanner, the scanners package will be empty. Instead of registering scanners, programmers will register tags. These will be cloned as needed to be returned as parsed nodes. I'm in a position now to remove the registerScanners() method, and I'm wondering if the state of a new Parser shouldn't be preloaded with tags it recognizes. This is directly opposite to the current implementation where one needs to do a two phase setup: I've looked at all the code I have available, and in every case (except for unit test cases) the new Parser call is immediately followed by registerScanners. Question: Should a new parser be already configured and ready to rock with tags registered? Of course there will be ways to get the original behaviour. After much discussion with Joshua, I've broken out the NodeFactory as a class, so currently this might look like (my unsubmitted codebase): where the boolean indicates the node factory should be constructed empty. Of course, you can add (or remove) whatever specific tags (even your own custom ones) you want to receive: which could also be written: An empty node factory generates undifferentiated tag, string and remark nodes, just like the Lexer. Then - I need to know how far I should go. Question: Should the node factory, and hence the Parser, have *all* the possible tags it knows about registered by default? This would be the equivalent of the current registerDomScanners() method call, which adds <HTML>, <HEAD> and <BODY> recognition. This may be slightly more problematical, since I can find very few (none?) instances of it's use. Realistically, if your program isn't handling recursing into node children now, you are probably doing it wrong, and adding one more level to the node tree won't cause a problem. My preference is to load it up completely, as it makes for a cleaner design, but if somebody can provide a compelling reason not to, I'll listen. In the absence of responses, I will take the answers as an emphatical Yes and Yes. Derrick

Good news and bad news Shaun. The bad news is I wasn't able to reproduce it. The good news is I think I know why it's happening. Here's a typical line from the URLs you encoded in the program: http://www.nba.com/playerfile/eddie_jones/index.html">Jones</a It starts with <td> and ends with </td>. That's good. But it has a <div> tag with no closing </div>, which is presumably what the <div> at the end was supposed to be. That's bad. http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/global.html#h-7.5.4 says <div> ends with </div>, i.e. it's required, not like </p> which is optional. Now, when the parser sees a <div> it tries to match it with </div> and fails, until much later in the page, leaving all the tags (like the table row and table data) also pending. This causes a recursion overflow for you. It's something we'll have to work on in the parser logic so this kind of page doesn't cause so much grief, but it's bordering on artificial intelligence to be able to discern that what they really meant was Until then you might try bumping up the memory available with something like: java -Xmx128M NBA_ScoreboardParser since these pages aren't too big and the extra memory might be enough to handle these errors. However, this won't give you a decent parse I'm afraid. Maybe it's enough for your purposes though. Derrick Shaun Roach wrote: http://scores.nba.com/games/20031028/scoreboard.html " http://scores.nba.com/games/20031029/scoreboard.html "

Thanks Derrick, It looks like the pages are just badly formed. I increased the memory = for java and more of the pages work that way. What is interesting is = that if I go through the code in debug mode, it works for EVERY page. = Thanks for all the time you took to find the cause of this problem, Shaun -----Original Message----- From: htmlparser-user-admin@... on behalf of Derrick = Oswald Sent: Mon 12/8/2003 7:21 PM To: htmlparser-user@... Cc:=09 Subject: Re: [Htmlparser-user] java.lang.StackOverflowError with Windows Good news and bad news Shaun. The bad news is I wasn't able to reproduce it. I found, however, that no TitleTag nodes are ever produced. It looks like I may have to register a TitleScanner. This leads me to two questions: 1. I can't find a good description anywhere of what, exactly, scanners do. 2. The ctor for TitleScanner takes a string argument described as the "filter". What in the world is a filter? Nowhere is this described in sufficient detail that I can figure out what string I should pass to the ctor (and why). Looking through the code, I see places where the TitleScanner ctor is passed "-t", "-T", and "", but I have no clue as to what differences these produce.

Kevin, Scanners are responsible for turning generic nodes into specific nodes (at least in the version you've got they do). The really useful ones (script scanner, jsp scanner come to mind) sort of take over the low level character by character reading of the URL to determine the extent of a tag. If you call parser.registerScanners() it will register the title tag and nearly all the other scanners too. This means that the specific TitleTag will be produced rather than just a generic Tag. You can register just the title scanner and you can give anything for a filter. It (was) used in the main line program to extract tags based on command line switches that matched, but that doesn't work very well since it doesn't dig recursively into the structure. That will go away in the next release. For extracting text content look at the StringBean. It won't do the title, but it does a fairly nifty job on the text. For a demo try: java -jar htmlparser.jar org.htmlparser.beans.BeanyBaby Hope this helps. Kevin S. Van Horn wrote:

How can I do that. When I use registerScanners, I get even more errors. Any suggestion? Thanks Navid __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Steve, The 1.3 NodeReader.getNextLine() issues that message when it encounters an IOException. It's unclear why it's looping though. Have you got a URL that causes it? Maybe there is a server-side problem and it drops the socket. Derrick Steve McCann wrote:

John, By default, unknown tag names will cause the parser to generate a generic Tag. The default tag is a simple tag, not a composite tag. What you probably want is to define a new composite tag, and then get it's contents after parsing (NOTE: this compiles but I can't test it, so you're on your own): public class RteExample public static void main (String[] args) throws ParserException parser = new Parser (" http://whatever list = parser.extractAllNodesThatMatch (new NodeClassFilter iterator.hasMoreNodes (); ) if (null != kids) for (int i = 0; i < kids.size (); i++) -- Derrick --------- John Moylan wrote:

Ayhan, I think it's a good idea for the parser to always use an english Locale when converting to upper case for tag names and attribute names. Thanks for pointing that overload out. I've identified about a dozen places where the String.toUppercase() is performed that should use a locale. I will implement this when the CVS system comes back online. You can track this with bug #883664 toUpperCase on tag names and attributes depends on locale. I'm surprised though, that your experiment didn't also find the end tag, which uses the same mechanism. Can you provide a URL that would illustrate the problem. My suspicion is the title tags are (incorrectly) built with Turkish characters. Perhaps you need to overload the TitleTag to recognize various combinations of English and Turkish characters, i.e. Title, TITLE, T\u0130TLE and T\u0131tle. These would convert to uppercase differently, based on the locale used. So you might define: public class TurkishTitleTag extends TitleTag /** * The set of names handled by this tag. */ /** * The set of tag names that indicate the end of this tag. */ /** * Return the set of names handled by this tag. * @return The names to be matched that create tags of this type. */ public String[] getIds () /** * Return the set of tag names that cause this tag to finish. * @return The names of following tags that stop further scanning. */ public String[] getEnders () Then you would substitute this tag for the normal TitleTag using something like: That should find all combinations of title, even without the toUppercase(locale) change, unless, of course, there are other special Turkish characters that need to be handled. Derrick p.s. Can you also provide a URL for the style problem. Ayhan Peker wrote: http://www.metu.edu.tr/about/admins.php
